column1: Michael Cunningham's "Flesh and Blood
column2: is one of the best novels I've read so far this year.   Constantine Stassos is a Greek immigrant with ambition, drive and a fierce temper. His wife Mary works hard to maintain the ideal or at least the illusion of perfection in her family. Constantine's three children are each touched, destroyed, or changed by their parents' behavior, especially their father's.   Cunningham's characterization is brilliant. Every thought, every action, every belief held by the people in Flesh and Blood" rings true and results in a stunning display of cause and effect.  Susan
column3: the eldest daughter is forever changed by her father's lack of boundaries
column4: and Zoe
column5: the youngest
column6: the one named for Constantine's Greek heritage
column7: is essentially ignored until the other two children have grown up and moved away from home. Constantine shows a unique tenderness to this wild child as they work together in the garden.  There's something different about Billy
column8: Constantine's only son
column9: and that fact haunts Constantine
column10: a feeling left unsaid-at least in the verbal sense-but always there between them nonetheless. Here's an excerpt:  "When Constantine hit him he felt he was obliterating a weakness in the house. He was cauterizing a wound. The back of his hand struck Billy's jaw hard
column11: scraped across his teeth with a cleansing burn. He heard Mary's scream from a distance. Billy's head snapped back and Constantine hit him again
column12: this time with the heel of his hand
column13: a smack solid and sure as a hammer driving a nail deep into pine."     The novel opens with a scene in which Constantine as a young boy works hard to make things grow
column14: going so far as to carry bits of rich soil in his mouth so that he may drop it onto his poorly soiled plot of a garden. The image of the garden shows up again when he and his daughter Zoe work to produce beautiful vegetables
column15: loaded with hidden caustic pesticides.   "She raised the tomato to her mouth
column16: and Constantine had an urge to yell
column17: `Don't it's poisoned.' Which was ridiculous. It was no more poisoned than most of what people ate
column18: and probably less. But as he watched her bite into the tomato
column19: a chill shot through his heart."  A stunning metaphor for the family affected by Constantine's devotion and poisonous weaknesses.

column1: This book looks deep beneath the surface of London society during the Age of Enlightment and describes in minute detail what life was really like for one and all
column2: from the lowest street urchin to the royal family.  The daily struggle for existence by London's residents is covered -- all those unsavory things you probably didn't learn in history class. Overflowing cespits
column3: Orphans apprentenced into professions where an early death from industrial pollutants was a near certainty
column4: bakeries that regularly adulterated their bread with caulk
column5: these are just a few of the many examples found on these pages. No detail is overlooked:  What they wore
column6: what they did for fun
column7: the cost of living
column8: the cost of dying
column9: the capricious justice system under which a significant number of lawbreakers managed to avoid punishment
column10: even for murder
column11: while an unlucky few were hanged for crimes that today would draw only a small fine. I highly recommend Dr. Johnson's London to anyone who is looking for an in-depth look at Georgian London.

column1: Sylvester and the Magic Pebble is William Steig's third book and the only book Steig wrote and illustrated that won the Caldecott Medal.  This story is about a donkey named Sylvester Duncan and his family.  Sylvester lives with his parents on Acorn Road in Oatsdale.  One of Sylvester's hobbies is collecting pebbles of unusual shapes and colors.  One rainy day Sylvester finds a red pebble that will grant him wishes.  On his way home to show the pebble to his parents a lion frightens him at Strawberry Hill.  To save himself he wishes he were a stone.  His problem was he could not wish himself back because the red pebble was not touching him because he was a rock with no hands.  A year passed and his family thought that they would never find their darling child
column2: until one day on a picnic at Strawberry Hill.  His parents eat on the very stone
column3: which is Sylvester.  His dad picks up the red pebble and wishes his son was with them.  The dad puts the red pebble on the stone and Sylvester wishes that they were back together and at that moment he is a donkey again. The family puts the rock away to wait until they really need something again.        Steig addresses the theme of children's fears of separation from their parents
column4: as well as their fears and terrors and even wishes for radical transformations.  Steig uses realistic fiction and animal fantasy in this book.  This is true because the book is about animals doing human like things
column5: which is Animal Fantasy.  The fact that Sylvester finds a magic pebble and turns into a stone is fantasy.  At the same time
column6: if you think of the characters as people
column7: this story could really have happened
column8: as far as people do have families
column9: they have picnics
column10: and children get separated from their parents.  I consider Sylvester and the Magic Pebble a good book.  Books for younger children usually focus on one or two main characters
column11: cover short time sequences
column12: and most often are set in one place.  Sylvester and the Magic Pebble has one main character
column13: Sylvester
column14: and it is set in two places
column15: Acorn Road and Strawberry Hill.  The time sequence is also very short.  Even though the book spaced over a year
column16: the time went by quickly.  Sylvester was a rock for each season and each page of the book had a new season
column17: therefore he was soon reunited with his family.  Sylvester is also supposed to be the age of a child
column18: therefore a child that reads this book will be able to identify with the central character.  This too is an example of a good book.  The language is concrete and vivid and not overly complex.  This story primarily names characters and their actions
column19: nothing too hard for a child to put together.  This book allows the reader to put themselves in Sylvester's shoes
column20: so they can have empathy for what it must be like to be separated from your family by accident.  This book does not overly teach a moral and is mostly an enjoyable read.  Once Sylvester's parents find him
column21: they do not even want to use the magic pebble anymore
column22: because they want nothing more then their son.  This shows that the book has truth to it with the human experience of realizing what you have once you have lost it.  The illustrations are equally as appealing as the text itself.  I love how William Steig is the author and illustrator in all his books.  Overall

column30: therefore I would absolutely consider Sylvester and the Magic Pebble a good book.  This book would be great to read in the classroom.  I thought of several teaching connections.  The book talks about a donkey that collects pebbles. You could talk to the class about collections and encourage them to share about ones they have or start a collection for the class.  Talking about different pebbles also allows for you to talk about the different kinds of rocks and gem stones. This is a great science lesson that you could even take a field trip to a gem mine and see what types of gems the students could find.  You could also use this book in talking about animals. This book does not show the typical animal actions
column31: but you could talk about how the animals in the book are trying to act more like humans and explain these differences.  You could also do an art lesson
column32: where students would find a large pebble and as a class everyone could paint pebbles.  You could also teach children how colors mix to make different colors during this lesson.

column1: Considering this band's penchant for mystery and a determined lack of publicity
column2: it's no surprise that most people think of Belle and Sebastian as a male/female duo. Rather
column3: they are a seven-piece band from Scotland
column4: making music that is very typical of their homeland; reflective and well-structured
column5: with a strong emphasis on poppish melodies (`pop' in the classic sense
column6: NOT in the contemporary boy-band sense). Of course
column7: Nick Drake comes to mind. And their Scottish predecessors
column8: Pre-Fab Sprout. Maybe a bit of Aztec Camera
column9: too. That's not a bad hybrid. Boy With the Arab Strap consists of fragile
column10: whispered melodies that convey innocence
column11: although the lyrics suggest something else entirely (the opening lyric is "He had a stroke at the age of 24..."
column12: for God's sake!). The dichotomy of gorgeous
column13: wispy music that sidesteps insouciance for self-analysis could be overbearingly precious if it were any less artful
column14: but the album maintains a sense of balance that keeps it from capsizing into a sea of narcissism. "It Could Have Been a Brilliant Career
column15: Sleep the Clock Around
column16: and the title track are some of the most melodious songs I've heard in quite a while. A strange, recited song called Space Boy Dream"
column17: with a TV-theme-type jazz-rock workout provides a bizarre but welcome mid-point
column18: and it segues so beautifully into the Motown stomp of "Dirty Dream Number Two" that it can generate goosebumps. This is not music for nightclubs. It is better suited to library lounges and bookstores - private moments rather than public ones - but the confidence of each song's performance belies alienation. Is it a natural ease that informs each song
column19: or is it ennui? Is the band enjoying a pastoral simplicity
column20: or is somebody going to end up at the end of a dangling rope? This much sensitivity indicates an equal amount of vulnerability
column21: which is exactly why these songs cannot be taken as lightly as the gently loping musical approach suggests. Even with the suggestion of such weightiness
column22: the songs are a genuine pleasure to hear
column23: flowing by as calmly as a country stream. Each arrangement suggests an attention to detail and generally upbeat sensibility that would (or should) transcend any unreasonable pathos that lies beneath
column24: making Boy With the Arab Strap an evocative and subtly moving work of art.	A		Tom Rya

column1: This book seems to be a shorter presentation of much of the material found in _The Absorbent Mind_
column2: which requires a good deal more persistence.  At less than 100 pages
column3: this book is easy to take in
column4: while still containing fundamental principles of Montessori's theory of education
column5: especially as relevant to 3- to 6-year-olds.  The writing is engaging
column6: not academic.  I can easily recommend it to be the first or only book by Dr. Montessori for the parent of a toddler to read.  There is not much here specifically relevant to the nature of elementary-level Montessori programs
column7: however.  Perhaps the foundational concept of Montessori's overall theory is that of the young child's "absorbent mind": "the child has a type of mind that absorbs knowledge
column8: and thus instructs himself."  The universal example is that of language acquisition
column9: which is flawlessly and gleefully accomplished by 2-year-olds who cannot read books or ask questions or attend lectures
column10: while the same entails a very laborious and error-prone effort for adults.  The child's mind is
column11: from birth
column12: forming itself and its "organs" (drawing an analogy to embryology) by its own natural impetus and direction.  Environment is key.  "[T]he child who
column13: making use of all that he finds around him
column14: shapes himself for the future."  Up until age 3
column15: the child's mind is "unapproachable by the adult
column16: who can exercise no influence on it."  From 3 to 6
column17: the child is able to tirelessly concentrate upon an environment carefully crafted with his or her psyche in mind
column18: absorbing its lessons.  Another fundamental concept in the theory is that of the "normal" child
column19: the "true" child which is revealed only when the environment is right.  Defects of character which may have been present before age 3 are resolved during the ages of 3 to 6
column20: if the provided environment plays to the power and nature of the absorbent mind.  The title of the book reflects the author's belief that the world which "has been torn to pieces" (presumably these words were written during or soon after WW2) can only be fundamentally reconstructed through education.  Children create themselves
column21: they create adults
column22: and thereby they are the creators of culture and civilization and the whole world -- they are all-powerful in this sense
column23: and therein lies the fundamentality of education as a cause of history.  Montessori also presents a notion of cosmic harmony
column24: such that every organism is performing the role it was perfectly designed
column25: through evolution
column26: to perform.  There is both a sense of a normally pleasant universe here
column27: as well as a questionable assumption of some important extra-personal purpose for each of us.  Not much in Montessori's program for 3- to 6-year-olds relies on this latter point
column28: that I can find.  Some other points discussed:  the importance of using the body
column29: especially the hands
column30: in learning; the stages of physical and mental development
column31: and of language learning; the small child's healthy motivation to complete tasks which may seem pointless to adults; the construction -- not "teaching" -- of moral character; obedience as obtained through freedom
column32: not fear; and what is required of the Montessori teacher or guide

column6: the theory went

column23: and Michael Johnston

There are also helpful screen captures and diagrams to explain key concepts.    ePhilanthropy is still an emerging and evolving field; this book provides clear support for any organization looking for guidance amidst this confusion.  Whether you are launching an online giving program

column30: this is a helpful new resource.  "Nonprofit Internet Strategies" should not only be a handy everyday reference

 Benedict Anderson's Imagined Communities" is justifiably a classic of political science and history. Its impact on the study of nationalism - which is arguably the ideology most resistant to academic study - can hardly be measured.  Anderson
column3: a specialist in South-East Asian history
column4: lets his scholarly instincts roam across the entire world as he seeks to explain just why it is that nationalism has become so prevalent in the world. What factors have meant that we take pride in someone dying "for our nation"
column5: while we don't take the same pride in someone dying "for our political beliefs"? The answer
column6: somewhat surprisingly
column7: begins with a description of the origins and impact of the printing press. Anderson's argument
column8: particularly the section most well-known to his readers
column9: is that the ability of those living in a particular place to read in their own language (as against Latin
column10: Arabic
column11: Sanskrit or Chinese) began this process. It was enhanced
column12: he contends
column13: with the production of newspapers
column14: allowing people to "imagine" themselves as Peruvian or Chilean
column15: rather than as Spanish colonials. Yes
column16: the choices of nation were used advisedly above
column17: as Anderson's second striking conclusion is that nationalism is a new-world (i.e. the Americas) phenomenon. The "Creole" intelligentsia
column18: allowed to progress only so far by their colonial rulers
column19: became the fertile ground necessary for nationalist ideals.  Anderson also discusses "official" nationalism in some depth
column20: focusing on Europe and making some quite surprising comments regarding the penetration of the various vernacular languages into their respective empires. This analysis seems a little more forced at times
column21: but the general point remains that a "nation" is essentially a modern and "imagined" community.  The revised edition of this work also goes into some detail about the roles of censuses
column22: maps and museums in the creation of nationalism. Using his South-East Asian training
column23: Anderson is able to explain such things as the importance of West Papua to Indonesia
column24: despite the marked cultural differences between most Indonesians and citizens of that province. While this analysis is self-consciously global in scope
column25: Anderson is modest enough to remind the reader that his training is in one region alone. This is a refreshing change from many scholars
column26: who propound theories of global scope based only on observations of a limited series of events.  "Imagined Communities" is
column27: as indicated above
column28: a read of considerable intellectual robustness. It is not
column29: however
column30: a read for the casual history-reader. Anderson makes many demands on his readers
column31: not the least of which is to follow his logic which is not always entirely apparent. With that in mind
column32: the book can be recommended to all with an academic interest in history

column1: This book
column2: with its initial copyright in 1936
column3: shows Christie at the height of her powers.  One of the coziest things about a Christie mystery - especially those which were written earlier - is that they are set before so many of the great advances in forensics.  There's no mention of computer databanks or DNA
column4: no fiber analysis nor hair samples.  Now
column5: I'm all for the wonderful things that can be done with forensics for capturing criminals in the real world
column6: and these can make for fascinating reading
column7: too.  But novels are sometimes more pleasant when they don't deal with the technical side of things
column8: but let the readers ponder
column9: along with Christie's detective Hercule Poirot
column10: the psychology behind the murder.  In Cards on the Table
column11: Christie sets up an imaginative
column12: elegant
column13: albeit implausible scenario.  Four murderers - successful ones
column14: those who have gotten away with it - are invited to dinner by Mr Shaitana
column15: a rich eccentric who collects only the best - including collections of people.  To the same dinner party this Shaitana invites four specialists in crime - a policeman
column16: a man in the Secret Service
column17: a writer of detective novels and of course our protagonist
column18: Hercule Poirot.  The dinner is excellent and Shaitana then makes some provocative remarks
column19: putting the wind up in his quartet of murderers.  The two groups - murderers and crime specialists - then divide into two different rooms and play bridge for the rest of the evening.  Shaitana does not play
column20: but sits in an armchair by the fire in the same room as the murderers.  The evening continues until late.  The crime specialists come to bid their host farewell
column21: when lo! - to their great surprise
column22: they find that their host has been murdered in the chair.  The deed must have been committed by one of the four bridge players during the course of the evening.  Christie then proceeds to reveal much about the murderers and their history.  She does her best to be fair during the course of the book
column23: putting her own cards on the table.  And of course the pool of those who could have committed the crime is also limited - in another sense
column24: the cards are also on the table.  Finally
column25: the bridge game plays a role in the assisting Poirot in figuring out whodunit.  You can enjoy this book if you don't know bridge
column26: but it helps if you do.  Another advantage of this book is that there's also no appearance of the dim Arthur Hastings
column27: for which I'm grateful.   The psychology
column28: in my opinion
column29: is spot on in this book
column30: and makes it one of Christie's best.  My only question - and one which she did not have to answer - is to wonder if Shaitana had any plans for the end of the evening
column31: assuming that he had survived?  But Christie is not obliged to answer this question
column32: and she does not.

This translation of Meditations by Maxwell Staniforth (this is not the Gregory Hays translation that a lot of people are reviewing) is the best I've read. It reads clearly and simply
column2: with no useless ornamentation to the text. Indeed
column3: what I like about the Great Ideas series that this is a part of is its lack of extras--forewords and introductions and the like which
column4: though often helpful
column5: are usually written by people other than the author and sometimes set the reader up to completely misinterpret what they are about to read. This copy of Marcus Aurelius is only Marcus Aurelius
column6: with perhaps a dozen or so explanatory footnotes sprinkled throughout.  The book itself is well-known
column7: content-wise. The titular meditations are bite-sized thoughts written down by Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius during his later years
column8: as he reflected on his past while campaigning in the north. He was one of the greatest and most famous stoics who ever lived
column9: and this book encapsulates his personal philosophy and manner of thought. His ideas are at once brilliant
column10: challenging
column11: and soothing
column12: making this book good down-time reading and an excellent gift for a friend. I've read it several times
column13: finding something new and moving every time. This is a very good edition of Meditations to have. The text is completely intact--not a selection--and the translation is clear and precise
column14: but never boring. Maxwell Staniforth has done us all a great service with this translation of the last good emperor's journals.  Highly recommended

column1: This book is a thoughtful and well-documented antidote to libertarian and conservative propaganda.  It shows exactly how racial discrimination permeated every layer of public and private life in both North and South -- and lasted well into the 1970s.  Before the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and during legal racial segregation
column2: especially under the GI Bill of Rights
column3: whites -- especially men -- benefited immensely and blacks were either denied benefits or prevented from getting them by local bureaucrats.  This is proof that we have barely begun to correct the effect of racial segregation on generations of Americans. White men benefited from quotas in the past.  They want to lose no priviledges.  Libertarians and conservatives want to keep those advantages for themselves and deny fair competition to all those against whom they discriminated in the past.  Color-blind policies now simply perpetuate the unfairness of a color-segregated past

In the bright daylight of modern day it's with some difficulty that one attempts to comprehend the horrendously monstrous things that the Nazi regime perpetrated against some of their fellow human beings. Everyone has read books or stories about the Nazi atrocities committed against the Jewish people
column2: but Ms. Pringle's highly researched book really delves deeper into the "Final Solution" of the Third Reich and details the acts of the  upper echelon of scientists and scholars involved in it.  All through this book I was wondering what could motivate seemingly "normal" people to devise and even participate in these terrible events? This even seems to be the author's final question about her own research. Probably the most striking thing about these events and the people involved in them is the fact that so many got away cleanly and continued to live normal everyday lives
column3: some even going on to great accomplishments in academia.  For anyone interested in the WWII era or interested in the true underlying framework behind the Holocaust
column4: I cannot more strongly recommend Ms. Pringle's book. Even for those like myself who have researched this area of history extensively
column5: one can still be shocked by the almost unbelievably heinous motivations and actions of those who actually carried out the "Final Solution"

column1: Rudy Baylor is a law student in his last year of law school. As one of his projects
column2: he is required to offer free legal advice to senior citizens at the local nursing home. Little did he realize that he would meet Dot and Buddy Black who would present to him the lawsuit of all times

column1: A balloon ride over Celesteville leads to Babar and Celeste deciding to turn in an abandoned train station into a museum in which they can display their great collection of fine paintings.  Everyone in town gets more and more excited waiting for the big day when the museum is opened and everyone can see everything that is hanging on the walls inside.  The paintings might be intended for the elephants and other animal friends of Babar and Celeste and this book might be intended for younger readers
column2: but the readers who will most enjoy Laurent De Brunhoff's book are going to be those old enough to appreciate the witty elephant-inspired version of great paintings from Michaelangelo's "Creation of Man" and Sandro Botticelli's "Birth of Venus" to George Surat's "A Sunday on La Grande Jatte" and Edvard Munch's "The Scream."  There is just something intrinsically enjoyable about taking Leonardi Da Vinci's "Mona Lisa" and making the lady with enigmatic smile an elephant
column3: and the idea of doing the same thing with Vincent Van Gogh's "Self Portrait" is hysterical since Babar is an African elephant and not an Indian elephant.  The more you know about great art the more you will enjoy strolling through the galleries with Babar and his family.  The book also includes a pull-out poster of the delightful art found in "Babar's Museum of Art."  The adventures of Babar have been delighting children for half a century and this is a charming addition to the series.  It should also inspire its young readers to check out the "real" versions of these great paintings so that they can find out what the adults are chuckling about as they enjoy "Babar's Museum of Art."  Is it too early to be thinking about books that would be great to give as gifts to young readers for Christmas?  This one should be high up on that list

Having just watched THE CONVERSATION for the first time
column2: I must say that I am utterly stunned.  It is one of the best films I have ever seen.  And to think
column3: I just added it to my queue on the off-chance that Francis Ford Coppola's other films in the 1970s would reveal some of the same mastery as the GODFATHER franchise.  Francis Ford Coppola is
column4: indeed
column5: at the top of his game in THE CONVERSATION and the director's own fascination with his own screenplay is evident.  While many have flagged this movie as a 1970s exploration of lies & secrecy stemming from the Watergate incident
column6: ultimately this film proves to be a character study on one of the saddest and complex characters ever to have graced the screen.    The film opens up with a masterful long shot of a park in San Francisco
column7: slowly zooming more and more on a character in the park
column8: whom we later find out is Harry Caul (masterfully played by Gene Hackman in one of the best performances of his career).  Caul looks about him nervously as if paranoid that someone is watching him.  Of course
column9: here we are
column10: silently hovering above him
column11: eavesdropping on Harry Caul's life.  It is the first of many such "voyeuristic" shots.  The plot soon becomes apparent.  Caul seems absorbed in following a couple as they walk around in circles in the park
column12: sharing a conversation.  Gradually
column13: it is revealed that there are several characters listening in with powerful directional microphones
column14: all orchestrated by the able hands of Caul.  Harry Caul is one of the best surveillance men in the country and we learn that he gets paid top dollar to do what he does best--tail people
column15: violate their privacy
column16: and emerge with an audio tape of their intimate conversations.  Using the various recorded bits of audio
column17: Harry is able to weave together a single master recording of the couple's conversation.  It is part art and part science.  Everything is going smoothly until Harry begins to listen to the content of his most recent assignment.  While piecing together the final tape
column18: Harry discovers that his tape may lead to the couple's harm.  Despite his professional oaths to complete the job and tune out the content of the audio
column19: Harry plays the tape over and over
column20: further convincing himself that he may be responsible for something terrible.  The truth is that this has happened to Harry before and he has never gotten over it.  Try as he might to cling to the scientific and technical aspects of his craft
column21: he is tortured by his knowledge.  As Harry begins to become more and more involved with his most recent assignment
column22: he becomes involved in a horrible and sinister plot that exposes him to just the sort of surveillance he fears.  What follows is Harry's descent into madness.  Given the nature of Harry's profession
column23: he is a paranoid person
column24: incredibly secretive and constantly convinced that he is being watched.  The sad irony of this fact is that Harry's life is so guarded and closed-off that there is nothing for other's to spy on.  In fact
column25: we (the audience) are the ones who are violating Harry's private life.  There is no pleasure in this voyeurism.  Watching Harry's sad life unravel is a painful experience.  And yet we cannot take our eyes away from the screen.  THE CONVERSATION grabs your attention from the top of the film and doesn't let you go for an instant.  Coppola's shots seem to purposefully mimic the movements of surveillance cameras.  The shots are left open
column26: characters walk in and out of frame
column27: culminating in the film's final shot--a perfectly timed pan (back and forth) across Harry's apartment that feels exactly like watching a surveillance monitor.      The twist at the end of THE CONVERSATION is shocking and mesmerizing--sparking as many questions as it answers.  If you haven't already seen this film
column28: you must drop what you are doing and see it right away.  Gene Hackman turns in one of the best performances of his career
column29: if not the best.  Normally
column30: Hackman plays supermen who are supremely confident of themselves.  It is amazing to see his transformation here
column31: a broken shell of a person
column32: sneaking around in a plastic see-through rain parka.  Coppola's direction is amazing and his camera work is perfectly calibrated to match the mood of the film.  The effect of the "voyeuristic" shots is that we feel like intruders into Harry's world
column33: eavesdropping on his private affairs.  And yet
column34: as close as we are brought to Harry
column35: the cold feel of the camera also serves to distance us at the same time.  I now have to see more of Coppola's work
column36: but I can say that this is (by far) the best film that I have seen Coppola direct.  Buy it today; rent it; watch it.

column1: I had a Norelco AccuTrim Beard and Moustache Trimmer T765 for a little over a year before I lost the charger. After looking for one both in town (San Diego) and on the Internet

column1: This has to be one of the saddest books I've read in a while.  It's beautifully ironic.  This book comes along and laments of the conflicts of interests with the marriage of universities and business while I am learning to embrace that I can love to have money.  I graduated from the University of Southern California and had a sense that something was amiss in the university system.  Back then
column2: I saw a university that catered strongly to the football program and felt like I was getting the scraps.  The football program brought in the money and with the latest successes some immeasurable advertising.  However
column3: there was an uneasy truce of advancing education and earning money.  A university gets all excited about a new corporate sponsor giving millions to a department.  But what if the corporate sponsor stipulates that the money be spent on research for the advancement of the sponsor's own products?  Or that any breakthroughs from the research would be considered the assets of the sponsor's?  And what happens when a professor mentoring graduate students is an owner of a private company?  In the former scenario
column4: the research would have a STRONG affinity toward saying something positive about the sponsor's product.  What department would say something bad about their sponsor even if research says so?  There's statistics that would be some bias.  In the second scenario
column5: the spirit of research/education in a university environment is stymied and looks more like competing departments in a business or competing businesses.  Instead of open sharing of ideas at the local coffeehouse
column6: students are making fake notes to disguise their research from each other.  In the final scenario
column7: we may have a professor who only supports a thesis that supports his stock portfolio.  I recommend the book for anyone who is in the process of higher education or thinking of going in that direction.  It could turn your head.  There's a whole lot of research and data in this book that began to numb my brain.  I give the book 4 stars because it was difficult to read - perhaps more because of the revelation of the corruption of higher education.  It will make a lot of you sick.

column1: I am sure the book is great-the book was purchased for a gift
Hank Hanegraaf
column2: president and CEO of the Christian Research Institute
column3: tackles some very controversial issues that exists in some churches today.  The book focuses primarily on two churches: one in Toronto and another in Pensacola
column4: Florida
column5: plus several individuals
column6: who all thrive on spiritually mystical
column7: or perhaps more accurately
column8: overtly sensational worship services.  The book carefully examines incidents of people losing entire control of their body
column9: either by freezing still for hours
column10: collapsing to the floor (also known as "being slain in the spirit")
column11: laughing continuously or shaking uncontrollably.  It also addresses reports of questionable healing and prophetic messages allegedly coming from God.  It's no understatement to say that it's a very scathing commentary about this movement.  Just about all the key figures are discredited either by exposing fraudulent accounts of what actually happened in these services
column12: or by accusing these people of inducing these behaviors by manipulative techniques
column13: or by exposing their secret un-Godly lifestyle.  One significant example was that the head pastor of the Toronto church
column14: who was married
column15: later died of AIDS due to allegedly engaging in a secret homosexual lifestyle.  By far the best part of the book is the final section where he thoroughly discusses psychological manipulation techniques such as hypnosis
column16: the power of suggestion
column17: the use of strong peer pressure and exploiting one's expectations in order to gain some desired results.  Another very damaging point made by Hanegraaf is that all of these seemingly supernatural behaviors are also commonly found in Hindu rituals performed by gurus and these same types of manifestations can also be induced by secular hypnotists.  The book also covers the history of the movement
column18: which really didn't start until around 1905.  I have only two minor criticisms of the book.  One is that it doesn't do an adequate job making it clear what worship should be.  He does brush over the topic with several Bible verses but I believe the that central point is missed. Worship is for God and not for man.  All believers must be focusing on glorifying God and praising Him for His majesty.  Laying unconscious on the floor doesn't do that
column19: nor is a person walking around like a chicken
column20: nor is a person quoting erroneous prophesy.  One example in the book quotes a prominent revival figure
column21: Bob Jones
column22: stating that
column23: "I figure if I hit two-thirds [of my prophetic messages]
column24: I'm doing pretty good".  Of course if prophesy is from God
column25: it should be 100% accurate.    The second criticism is that it should have made it clear that real healing and other miracles are still possible and believers should still pray for God's will in those matters.  Again these are minor points and I still highly recommend this book.  I would more accurately give this book 4-1/2 stars if the system allowed

column1: An amazing analysis of the perceptual principles involved in film viewing.  Arnheim provides a fascinating and scholarly look at the psychological and physiological aspects of cinema. A profound and thought-provoking work
There is
column2: throughout Terry Pratchett's "Sourcery
column3: a somewhat sorrowful tone being struck amidst the high spirited comedy and dramatic saving the world (again) sorts of action.  Because, at the heart of this story of how a most magical being, one whose very existence could unravel the fabric of the universe, is a scared and cruelly tormented little boy. That Pratchett keeps this in mind, and indeed, makes his salvation just as important as saving the world, is a credit to his skills as a writer and heart as a person.  The eighth son of an eighth son is a wizard. And the eighth son of a normally celibate wizard is a sourcerer, a living font of magical energies. But it's slightly more complicated than that: a father with a grudge against the magical establishment, a magical establishment (the cast of Unseen University, alternately pathetic and for once frightening) that's hungry for power, and a chain of events that quickly gets out of control all hurtle this story towards disaster.  Along the way, we get introduced to the daughter of the greatest hero in Discworld's history, who just desperately wants to be a hairdresser but finds that some things are just in her blood. We also pick up a very unlikely barbarian hero and a literary minded monarch and his fabulous pleasuredome. And, of course, the magic-less wizard Rincewind and his animate Luggage make a triumphant (well, as triumphant as Rincewind gets) return.  Sourcery" is Pratchett's most heartfelt novel to date
column4: and he puts the characters ahead of plot or jokes -- although there are plenty
column5: especially concerning Conina and Unseen University -- and it makes for one of the best Discworld novels to date.  Strongly recommended

column1: Some women want to strangle models
column2: but most people don't actually go that far. That's not the case in "Blood and Black Lace
column3: where models run, scream, and die in all sorts of gruesome ways. Mario Bava's classic giallo has some monotonous moments, but mostly it sticks to stylish slayings.  Just before a fashion show, the model Isabella is found dead in a wardrobe. The police investigate the fashion house's various models and managers, but can't find any solid evidence. And during the show, one of the other models finds Isabella's diary, which is loaded with scandalous information about drugs, lovers, abortions, and debts.  But then the diary is stolen, and trenchcoated killer waits until the models are alone -- and then he burns, strangles, drowns, and claws them. The police suspect the men -- designers and managers -- at the fashion house, but even detaining the suspects won't stop the gruesome murders...  At first glance, Blood and Black Lace" seems like just another bloody slasher movie. Well
column4: giallo is to slasher movies as fine cheese is to Velveeta
column5: and "Blood and Black Lace" is a perfect example of a giallo
column6: with the arty lighting
column7: graphic violence
column8: colourful sets
column9: and of course those black gloved hands.   The plot is a pretty straightforward whodunnit -- it's not blatantly obvious who the killer is
column10: but seasoned movie fans can probably guess. And while there are gruesome slayings
column11: the killer doesn't just jump out and kill. Bava builds up the tension and fear (which the characters also demonstrate) until it's almost a relief when someone dies.  But one of the biggest necessities for a giallo is visual style. The fashion house is lushly palatial
column12: and the murders are elaborately choreographed chases
column13: with weird lighting and lots of luxurious surroundings. The second murder
column14: for instant
column15: is like hide-and-seek in an antiques store. The only problem is a misogynistic edge
column16: such as when the women have their shirts ripped halfway off.  None of the characters really stand out much -- they're the Models
column17: the Creepy Boyfriends
column18: the Skeptical Police
column19: the Weird Landlady
column20: and a handful of others. So it's a credit to the actresses like Mary Arden and Eva Bartok that they are able to make us feel sorry for their characters.   "Blood and Black Lace" is a beautiful
column21: bloody guilty pleasure
column22: and a perfect example of a giallo horror movie. Good stuff

column1: Peter  de Krassel's book is a beam of light through a pitch-black series of essays on our present time in history. His viewpoint serves as an indicator that illuminates understanding for how we arrived into our contemporary drama and provides impetus for embracing recognition of a global community. Includes opportunity for amazement and many good chuckles
column2: as well as a view of Hong Kong that we ordinarily are not privy to experience from our receiving end of the media's voice. Inspiring and challenging with a delicious sense of connectedness served with humor and sensitivity beyond outrage

column1: My husband and I did a similar thing to David's family--we skipped out on our "happy perfect" lives in a quaint New England town
column2: to give rough and tumble Dublin a go.  We've never looked back and David's book is the one we'd write
column3: if we had his eye for a story and his talent for telling it.  This man knows of what he speaks
column4: when it comes to capturing the expat life in an accurate and compelling fashion.  I am amused to see the American reviews focus
column5: I think
column6: somewhat overly much on the negative sides of the Monagan adventure.  If they didn't have mistakes and dark encounters
column7: what stories would they have to tell?  Living in Ireland
column8: I read those stores with both recognition but awareness of the hugely compensating postive sides of what the Monagans did.  If you have any interest in what it is like for an American family to live in a foreign country
column9: and you want to hear it "told straight"
column10: run to buy this book. I read loads of this genre and this is definitely one of the better selections (along with Paris to the Moon by Adam Gopnik)

column1: Crystal Method showed us their skills as DJs in addition to producing on their 2001 mix
column2: "Community Service"
column3: They're back at it with this offering
column4: and they don't disappoint!  Rising stars like Evil Nine and Elite Force feature alongside "names" you may recognize like Koma + Bones and Meat Katie.  The breaks are relentless

column12: which borrows extensively from the original without adding anything special or new
column13: and is also the most subdued track on the mix...a necessary come-down from the beats?

column1: This is a great childrens book but also great for young adults. It is a wonderful story about the apprentice becoming the teacher uing strength and courage to overcome troubles
Have you ever thought you wanted to learn how to program
column2: and bought a book on programming that didn't teach you anything?  Or maybe you took a class that had a required textbook that was worthless?  Did you get discouraged
column3: and think programming just wasn't "for you"?  That maybe you just didn't "get it" like those other people that seemed to have no problems learning to program?  If so
column4: then this book is for you.  If more computer programming books were written like this
column5: I KNOW there'd be a lot more programmers in the world.  It's not about intelligence
column6: it's about LEARNING STYLES.  This book is more narrative than just lines of code to interpret.  John Smiley talks TO the reader
column7: not AT him.  He puts you in a classroom setting where people ask questions
column8: even DUMB questions that you yourself may have wanted to ask.  And guess what?  He ANSWERS the questions.  If you've been stymied in one way or another from reaching a point of confidence with programming then this book is for you.  I give it 5 stars because that's the most that Amazon's system will let me give it.  If you don't believe me
column9: hit the library.  Then buy the book to put food on this man's table
column10: and have this awesome book in your personal library

column1: 'The Untold Story' is purportedly based on a true story. If that is indeed the case
column2: this film is one of the more horrifying endeavors I have had the pleasure to witness in all my years. Even if it is not
column3: this still quite a film...  Herman Yau directed this HK horror masterpiece masterfully. Anthony Wong (as Kai) gives one of the most convincing psycho performances I have ever encountered (at that's saying a lot)...  The story is a relatively simple one (albeit very effective). At the outset
column4: Kai and his boss have some sort of monetary dispute involving gambling and cheating. An argument ensues
column5: at which point Kai than proceeds to go sickhouse
column6: and kill the man... Fast forward 8 years...  Kai is running a restaurant. Mysteriously
column7: the previous owner and his family are nowhere to be found. As the police and various people begin to inquire about how Kai came into ownership of the restaurant
column8: the questions begin to pile up (as do the missing bodies)...  Kai
column9: being witty as well as psychotic devises a clever and creative way to dispose of the various bodies that he has created. By the way
column10: don't eat the 'pork buns'...   Eventually the local police (who are portrayed as silly
column11: Police Academy-esquire buffoons) become suspicious
column12: leading to the arrest and eventual imprisonment of Kai. Torture and brutality ensue
column13: culminating in a coerced confession presented beautifully and horrifically by Yau...  Much has been made of the violent and wicked nature of this film. Perhaps I am jaded
column14: but I did not find this film to be gratuitously violent. All of the violent and wicked acts depicted were in context
column15: and served the purpose of showing what a monster Kai is..  This may sound like a rather simple film. Plotwise it is. However
column16: the story was well-constructed
column17: and Yau's capable direction keep things moving forward engagingly so. This is a captivating and enthralling story
column18: all the more incredible because it allegedly happened. If you love a good true crime/horror story (and are not of the squeamish variety)
column19: you will most likely find this to be a fascinating and well-done film...

column1: Greek village life has been disappearing rapidly over the past 30 years as the actual villagers have died off. But this study was made over 100 years ago
column2: when villages were thriving with thousands of people
column3: and the direct connections between their religious and cultural practices and their ancient ancestors as shown in this book make it an incredibly important and truly invaluable historical document

column1: Harvey's last novel (In A True Light
column2: his first after the ten-book Charlie Resnick series)
column3: left Nottingham for London and New York. This very good new book returns to familiar environs
column4: with the majority of the action taking place in the Midlands
column5: including Nottingham (Charlie Resnick even has a cameo walkon) and the Cornish coast. The protagonist is a familiar type for Harvey
column6: Frank Elder is a retired Detective Inspector who left the police force to lead a hermit's life on the coast following the end of his marriage (the details of this are laid out in a short story called "Due North" which has appeared in several anthologies
column7: including Crime in the City). He lives in a small cottage and is haunted by gruesome nightmares
column8: as well as the knowledge of his wife's adultery and his lackluster performance as a father to their teenage daughter.   Also haunting Elder is an old case from 1988
column9: a brutal rape and murder committed by a pair of sadistic men who may have killed another teenage girl who disappeared at the same time. The parole of one of the men spurs him to leave his hermitage and start poking around the cold case of the missing Susan Blacklock. Much of the book alternates between Elder's investigation and the parolee's fractured attempt to make it on the outside. The parolee disappears at the same time another teenage girl is murdered
column10: and Elder is brought into the investigation as a consultant. Most of the book proceeds in the typically tight and angst-ridden prose that characterized Harvey's Resnick series. The procedural angles are all covered very well
column11: and Harvey does an excellent job of peeling away the layers to get to Elder's inner fears and disappointments. His awkward relationship with daughter is handled very well (the father/daughter relationship drives the plot of In A True Light)
column12: as his is uncertain romance with a middle-aged woman.   There are two flaws in the book
column13: neither major
column14: but enough to keep the book out of the superb category. One is Harvey's succumbing to the unfortunately tendency of crime novelists to make their plots and villains intersect with the hero's friends and family. It gives nothing away to say that's what happens here
column15: and the result cheapens the story. The other flaw is the unnecessarily pay-off of Elder's nightmares
column16: which are revealed as being exactly prescient. This introduces an odd quasi-mystical element to an otherwise entirely gritty and realistic story
column17: and serves no good purpose. These are minor bumps
column18: though
column19: and Harvey's fans and newcomers will find plenty to like about this fine crime novel. Elder returns in Harvey's next novel
column20: Ash and Bone.   NOTE: The American dust jacket of this and In A True Light are terrible--they are garish and completely fail to convey the tone of the novels. It's a mystery as to why they don't just go ahead and use the art from the UK editions
column21: which is much better.

column1: This book should be on the reference shelf of anyone designing or evaluating logos. It is compact and packed with information on shapes
column2: images and symbols from the perpectives of cultures around the world - from  prehistory forward. It is illustrated and cross-referenced. Grab it several  time throughout the design process to make sure you are on target with the  symbolism inherent in the shapes and images you are using in your designs.  Great value

column1: I just read the review from S. Haus
column2: and I believe she missed the meaning of this book.  It is entertaining and informational.  It is not meant to be a "How To Primer".  It is an observation of how modern conveniences can be integrated into the colonial style house and not ruin the original quality of the home.  It is also a historical view of how these homes have evolved through the years. If she were familiar with this author
column3: she would know that many of her works offer a historical chronology of how architecture and furniture styles have evolved.  I personally loved the book as well as the book "Bungalow Style" and have sent dozens of copies to my relatives and friends as gifts.  I believe that when Mr. and Mrs. Haus move to Boston
column4: they should invest in a decorator instead of a book if they want historical accuracy without being "too dark"

column1: This book is a remarkable feat of scholarship
column2: especially in its ablility to remain highly readable despite its scholarship.  We find here a very human portrayal of a man struggling to literally embody God
column3: and
column4: despite the scope of such circumstances
column5: we are oddly able to empathize with Jesus. He confronts his extraordinary situation
column6: paradoxically
column7: as an ordinary man.     The spareness of the biblical style helps us forget the author and the complex theological and historical weight that the story carries.  We are able to focus on the personal
column8: day-to-day
column9: hour-by-hour inner life of Jesus
column10: the man.     If you expect quirks and controversy
column11: forget it.  If you expect either a born-again
column12: hysterical excitement or a ponderous intellectual examination
column13: take a pass.  But
column14: if you are looking for an intimate look at the plausible humanity beneath the religeous and emotional furvor
column15: then read this book.     Mailer's account is particularly comprehensible to the 90's mind in that he allows us to see Jesus coping consciously with the dangers his "celebrity" as a miracle worker begin to pose.  In our celebrity conscious
column16: media saturated time
column17: we are perhaps more ready to appreciate the "crowd-control" aspects of the story of Christ
column18: and the practical and psychological impact that those factors must have had on Jesus' day-to-day decisions.     So how can a jewish author in the 1990's create a plain spoken text in biblical dialects that becomes an exciting "page turner" even though we all know from page one exactly how it is going to turn out in the end?  No matter how unlikely
column19: Mr. Mailer has accomplished that feat.  Read it with an open mind and your mind will open still further.

column1: The farther we get from Larry Niven's original Ringworld book
column2: the more the central characters evolve and change
column3: just as the Ringworld itself changes.  Not only do we learn more about the nature of the Ringworld itself and how the interference of many protagonists has changed (and almost destroyed) it
column4: but we learn how the natives have changed as well.  For me
column5: this is the essence of science fiction
column6: and it's a pleasure to watch a master at his craft.  Nivin's writing
column7: too
column8: has changed over the last 35 years
column9: which is hardly surprising
column10: and his readers' tastes have undoubtedly changed
column11: too.  Larry has other
column12: newer things to say today
column13: and they're worth reading.  You need not have read the previous three books
column14: but might be a good idea; the Ringworld books tell a complex story
column15: and if it's been a while since you've read them
column16: it certainly wouldn't hurt to do a bit of review.  Larry updates his slant on technology
column17: but he does it in a way that weaves it into the previous books.  This may jar some readers
column18: but it has
column19: after all
column20: been 35 years.  Recommended

this is a disturbingly fanciful mystery about what could have happened if the evil Dr. Mengele's bizarre experiments had worked out to the Third Reich's advantage.  I was very impressed with the on screen chemistry of Cate  and Giovanni Ribisi in the  movie The Gift" so I was delighted to find them both appearing in this movie. The plot concerns a  justice seeking killing which goes wrong and Mr. Ribisi's character throws away his everyday life as a Police Interpreter to be with Cate's character and then they are on the run from the law. The silences between sentences in this movie speak volumes and Cate gives us an excellent performance in a not so glamourous role and Mr. Ribisi is as close to perfection as an actor can get. This movie is also enhanced by the stunning Italian vistas. Bravo to all for the making of this excellent and most thought provoking film

column1: If you're one of King's constant readers you will agree that The Talisman was all King.  Black House seems all Straub.    The narratvie reads like a screenplay
column2: which at times is drudging.      You look and look and sometimes you find King
column3: buried in a sentence here and there ... here and now.  But (and here I'll use Black House style of narrative) as we float over Straub's neighborhood
column4: and as we float over the Safeway
column5: which  seems to have a sale on toilet paper
column6: we reach Mr. Straub's home.  He is scratching his head with one hand while the other tentative hand is resting on the keyboard of his computer.  He's stuck.  He can't seem to come up with the next sentence.  Then he 'flips' and there is King
column7: next to him
column8: and he whispers into Straub's ear
column9: and Straub has the next sentence.  So as we read Black House we know it's Straub
column10: but the haunt of King is evident throughout the novel.  It's Straub's writing style
column11: but it's King's imagination.  Oh
column12: and the DT tie-in's are executed masterfully

column1: Far Tortuga is one of the finest works of fiction I have ever read.  Had this book been written a hundred years ago

column5: and shorn of everything that is not necessary (unlike Conrad's heavy-handedness).  Even though we (ironically) live in an age of some fine writing

column7: gains some readers
column8: gets some good reviews
column9: and is forgotten.  It's not Matthiessen's fault; it's just that anything today of real quality is noticed by fewer and fewer people.  Far Tortuga is a dream.  Please read it
column10: you won't be disappointed

column1: This is fantastic journalistic-style fiction that has all the elements of a great book:  gambling
column2: Vegas
column3: murder
column4: sex
column5: and the potential for personal ruin.  This book is ostensibly about the murder of Ted Binion and the sex/money scandal surrounding that.  This storyline is what sucks the reader in
column6: but McManus quickly abandons that story for a much
column7: much more fascinating one about playing in the World Series of Poker
column8: held at Binion's Horseshoe and founded by the Binion family.  McManus was sent by Harper's magazine to cover the Binion story
column9: but he's a cocky poker player himself
column10: so he puts his welfare and relationship with his wife on the line by taking his entire advance and playing into the World Series.  Knowing that McManus has his own money on the line
column11: and he's not funded by the magazine to make a good story
column12: makes this journey absolutely amazing.  McManus teaches the reader how to play poker and gives the basics of the poker masters' strategies
column13: so that the reader is able to play along with the highs and lows of the game.  McManus even finds himself playing against people whose poker books he has read
column14: so he knows what they taught him and the rest of the world about poker
column15: which makes for interesting mind games at the table.  I would love to give this book 5 stars
column16: but there is some material in here which really should have been edited out.  McManus goes off for pages about how he knows David Sedaris or the illustrator of Me Talk Pretty One Day
column17: or some other fact that is unrelated to the book and serves only to prove how cosmopolitan the author is.  He also gives not only his childhood story
column18: but that of his father and grandfather
column19: and I found those to be very trying chapters that distracted from the high paced action of the book without adding any real meat to the story.  This is a great intro to poker
column20: and McManus gives the reader enough info to get them intersted in the game
column21: and to know what books and software to check out if they want to start playing.  I highly recommend this book to any non-fiction lover

column1: After a rocky start in the late 70s and early 80s
column2: the Eurythmics focused all of their talent and experience to produce the defining moment of their career.  The most memorable point in this moment was the video for "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)."  During the baby stages for MTV
column3: most of the videos were cheesey and embarrassing.  A few artists were so cool
column4: though
column5: that they stood out among the rest.  The Eurythmics were one of those; they truly raised the standards for making videos.    Beyond the videos
column6: the music on this album is what's really important.  With "Sweet Dreams" and "Love Is A Stranger
column7: Annie's bitterness about love is surrounded by Dave's pulsating synthetic beats and soft, dissonant laser chimes.  By just listening to these two songs, one would think that the Eurythmics had become a full-fledged New Wave synth band; and there are certainly other songs on here to appease that taste (I've Got an Angel
column8: I Could Give You A Mirror").  But
column9: the band refuses to be categorized.  Several songs are textured by Dave's sleek guitar licks
column10: adding some blues ("Wrap It Up") and even a tinge of latin ("This Is the House").    From beginning to end
column11: "Sweet Dreams" flexes its muscles and relaxes
column12: then flexes again and finally sighs with the brilliant "This City Never Sleeps."  In fact
column13: there is not a dull moment on this recording.  While most of the albums from the eighties New Wave craze have dated and fallen into novelty
column14: "Sweet Dreams" will remain one of the definitive albums of the genre and decade.  Truly a one-of-a-kind Masterpiece

 Ray Kroc's success story is quite a record of persistence and achievement. He didn't invent the McDonald's chain (as many erroneously believe) but he knew a winner when he saw one and he negotaited to buy the business. He truly believed that McDonald's could be a huge, global operation if it was promoted right and run with an emphasis on quality, customer service, cleanliness, and value. These four attributes made the acronym QSCV"
column22: and it was something that Ray Kroc preached to his people every single day.   Ray Kroc shows his confidence throughout the book
column23: not just with business
column24: but also in his personal life. He pursued his business dreams with unmatched vigor
column25: and he was equally determined to reach his personal goals. His relentless courtship of Joni
column26: his one true love
column27: is one of the highlights of the book. It's fun listening to Kroc spill his heart out
column28: telling the reader all sorts of details about his personal life. He was absolutely ga- ga over his beloved Joni
column29: and he shows no embarrassment in admitting his feelings. Here was a man who had the world in his hands
column30: a senior citizen who was head of a large corporation
column31: and yet he was completely
column32: hopelessly in love and willing to give it all up for his number one lady. He was having trouble sleeping
column33: and couldn't concentrate on work anymore. He was like a starry- eyed teenager
column34: always in a daydream- like state
column35: fantasizing about the woman he loved. He was prepared to do virtually anything to capture her heart.   Kroc was an outspoken and egotistical man
column36: and these personality traits pop up throughout the book. He blew his top several times
column37: when things didn't go his way or when someone would make a negative comment about McDonald's
column38: and he could often be quite profane and a little vile. This was true in his other business ventures as well like when his San Diego Padres baseball team (he was the owner) wasn't performing up to par. There was one episode
column40: when the Padres played miserably and Kroc let them know exactly how bad they were. It was the home opener
column41: and at its conclusion
column42: Kroc grabbed the public address microphone and harshly criticized the players for such a lousy performance. The media jumped all over the incident
column43: but Kroc was undeterred. He gave no apologies
column44: feeling that the team was letting down the fans and deserved to be chewed out.   One place where Kroc didn't let his ego get in the way with smart business was with the naming of the restaurant. He decided to keep the original name
column45: McDonald's
column46: rather than using his own name. This was a wise move
column47: especially considering Ray's last name. Would you want to visit a restaurant that was named "Kroc's"? Just the name alone would make me lose my appetite and it was a wise business decision to keep the original name intact.   This book shows occasional dabs of humor and some good writing. Kroc and editor Robert Anderson both deserve credit for making the book more enjoyable to read with its easy- flowing style. It's not awash in humor
column48: but there's enough to help keep the book interesting. One criticism that I have of this book
column49: however
column50: is the layout; specifically
column51: the fact that the chapters have no titles
column52: which is inexcusable. Titles are helpful for reference purposes
column53: and they should have been included. If Ray Kroc didn't realize this
column54: then the editor should have. Other than that
column55: the book is well- written and partically error free from a grammatical standpoint.   Kroc tells his story with gusto and pride. You can tell that he's very happy with the McDonald's company and gleaming with satisfaction over the way his personal life and professional life have turned out. This book was written in 1977
column56: and much has changed since then
column57: both with McDonald's and with fast- food in general. There are far more choices in fast- food today
column59: which had not yet achieved a substantial share of the market back when Ray Kroc wrote this book. It's hard to say how Kroc would have reacted to these modern- day changes in the marketplace
column60: but I'm sure he would have welcomed the challenge.   Many people don't prefer McDonald's food
column61: but the man behind the arches
column63: is a person who deserves respect. His tenacity was unrelenting
column65: and his drive to succeed was unstoppable. He took a small
column66: roadside restaurant in California and transformed it into the world's largest fast- food chain. "Grinding it Out" is a testament to the difference that one man can make when he has guts and determination to be the best.

column1: An interesting book giving a snapshot of one family every generation from 1066 in Sussex

column4: and I would recommend this book to anyone wanting to read a generational snapshot of an ordinary family set in the context of national and international events

column1: I've watched a lot of television in my 28 years. I've read newspaper articles
column2: seen press conferences
column3: and listened to radio interviews. But I never realized the deliberate steps those people were taking to get their message across.  I had no idea that there was a thought process behind how often to plug your new venture in a radio interview (as opposed to a newspaper interview). I didn't realize that you should address a T.V. reporter differently (and more often) than reporters in other media. And I certainly didn't think about the methods used to create those "talking points" we hear so much about these days.  I'm not sure this book prepared me to immediately jump in front of the cameras. But
column4: it caused a definite shift in my thinking. This book is an important first step for anyone who is naive about the effort required to effectively communicate with the public (via the press). It's also vital for those who are cynical about preparing for interviews
column5: or worried about "selling out" for the purpose of gaining attention.  This book could easily be subtitled "How To Respect Your Audience." Mr. Walker spends a fair amount of time explaining that when you don't properly prepare yourself and your message
column6: you do a huge disservice to your audience. I recommend this book as a primer in dealing with the media.  It gives lot of techniques with examples.  But
column7: most importantly
column8: it explains the rationale for each tip.  Because all the techniques
column9: tips
column10: and tricks in the world won't help you if you don't firmly understand and believe in the power of preparation

column1: This has been the third novel I have read by John Irving.  The reason why I gave it four stars and not five is because at times I felt that the story was a bit too long winded. It appeared that John Irving had difficulty getting to the point at certain times of the story.  I also felt that he didn't tie up all the loose ends.  I will not go into that detail as I don't want to give too much away.  But with that aside
column2: it was a terrific story not just about a man from Bombaby
column3: but about people from all different walks of life.  What I like about John Irving is that he writes in such a way that I almost feel that I am living along with the characters he created.  Yes
column4: it is a long book
column5: but I wasn't able to put it down because I was always yearning to know what was going to happen next.  This is one of those books that I will be able to remember for a long time as the characters and story is very poignant. Who knows
column6: I might even give it a re-read further down the road.  All in all a great book that will sit on my bookshelf for a very long while.
