This is the only book of Prof. Kissinger's that I have read
column2: and I have to say that I am not as impressed by it as I thought I would be.  There is no doubt about his intelligence and wide range of knowledge
column3: but he has the diplomat's habit of getting bogged down in the details and in the process forgetting his main point.  Here is the final paragraph in the book:  "While traditional patterns are in transition and the very basis of experience and knowledge is being revolutionized
column4: America's ultimate challenge is to transform its power into moral consensus
column5: promoting its values not by imposition but by their willing acceptance in a world that
column6: for all its seeming resistance
column7: desperately needs enlightened leadership."  Well
column8: yes
column9: and
column10: as Rodney King said
column11: "Why can't we all just get along?"  Content aside
column12: the above quotation is a one-sentence paragraph containing 52 words
column13: a typical sample of Kissinger's turgid
column14: unimaginative
column15: and bureaucratic prose style.  One can almost hear his droning accent as one tries to follow these interminable ramblings.  So:  His style is abysmal and his conclusions either naive or disingenuous.  He KNOWS we live in a world dominated by force
column16: that platitudes are not going to keep us safe and secure
column17: and that perhaps even the SEARCH for safety and security is a chase after rainbows.  As a long-time advocate of realism in foreign policy he should be able to come up with something with a little more depth than this.  In spite of these defects this book is well worth reading.  Although the first six chapters
column18: the bulk of the book
column19: are primarily an indictment of Bill Clinton's foreign policy (or lack thereof)
column20: the last chapter contains two very helpful and informative discussions.  The first section of this chapter is a review of the basic historical approaches to American foreign policy
column21: which he has identified as "Hamiltonian"
column22: "Jacksonian"
column23: and "Wilsonian".  The "Hamiltonian" is a tradition of practical balance-of-power maneuver advocated most vigorously in the early years of our Republic by Alexander Hamilton
column24: whose first concern was to make sure America avoided being trapped and destroyed by the military monarchies then ruling Europe.  The "Jacksonian" tradition
column25: named for President Andrew Jackson
column26: more or less corresponds with Isolationism as advocated and practised for most of the 19th century and during the interwar years of the 20th century.  It was a reflection of the development of American self-confidence and relative geographical isolation from the wars of Europe.  The "Wilsonian" tradition
column27: originating with Woodrow Wilson
column28: has been the major influence on American foreign policy since WWII.  It aspires to make the world over in America's liberal democratic image.  The speeches of George W. Bush could easily have been delivered by Wilson himself.  And the Democrats
column29: who are now so viciously attacking Bush and his policies
column30: when in power have been vigorous advocates of the Wilsonian approach.  When Kissinger himself was in power and responsible for liquidating the American position in Vietnam
column31: it seems to me he followed a pretty orthodox "Hamiltonian"
column32: not to say "Machiavellian"
column33: approach to foreign policy.  It is therefore surprising to hear him sounding so Wilsonian in this book.  One has to wonder if he is being sincere.  Nevertheless
column34: he knows his  subject and presents it well.  The last section of the last chapter
column35: on Universal Jurisdiction
column36: is also very well done.  In the preceding chapter he reviews the basic motivations and concepts of the Treaty of Westphalia
column37: that in 1648 stopped the barbaric blood-letting of the Thirty Years' War.  He then shows how the recent preoccupation with Universal Human Rights
column38: and especially the setting up of the International Criminal Court in 1998
column39: completely overturns the settlement so painfully reached at Westphalia.  (It should be noted that Westphalia is a province of Germany.  The treaty is named after a province because the parties to the treaty were too hostile to meet in the same city.)  Of course
column40: as many have pointed out
column41: Kissinger has a dog in this fight.  Serious proposals have been made by his political enemies to prosecute him for war crimes
column42: much as Pinochet was indicted by Spain and arrested in Britain for "crimes against humanity" that occurred in Chile.  Kissinger
column43: however
column44: is not the only person whose personal security is placed at risk by this new and intensely idealistic focus on transnational prosecutions.  Under this doctrine all American military and diplomatic personnel serving overseas are potentially liable to criminal prosecution by third parties for actions taken in the line of their official duties.  Kissinger rightly points out that this unprecedented development has the potential to massively increase the difficulty of America's pursuit of its national security in a dangerous world.  In summary
column45: this book doesn't live up to its title.  However
column46: it should be read for Kissinger's description of the major historical trends of American foreign policy and for his analysis of the doctrine of Universal Jurisdiction

column1: Dr. Geoffrey Miller
column2: in The Mating Mind
column3: offers a hypothesis regarding the brain that is truly exciting. He postulates that our advanced functioning evolved at a rapid pace due to sexual selection. Women
column4: over thousands of years began to show preference for men with large brains featuring creative intelligence and expansive verbal ability. Unlike with a peacock's tail
column5: the brains of females also developed to enable them to discriminate amongst the men they encountered in the hopes of selecting the finest specimen. Many speculate that a good deal of our early mating was a result of rape
column6: and that men took women when they saw them
column7: but this was generally not the case. Husbands
column8: fathers
column9: brothers
column10: cousins
column11: and sons have always shown an aversion to their female relations being raped
column12: and
column13: throughout history
column14: women largely have been free to choose the best males with whom to mate.  Miller's theories are extremely intriguing
column15: and I do not regard them as being mutually exclusive with the predominant view that our minds evolved as a means to overcome the complex environmental challenges of our existence. This may have been why women showed the preference for large brains that have over time. I think both concepts are harmonious with one another.  As a writer
column16: Miller has a lively pen and does not overburden readers with scientific lingo. This book is definitely geared for a popular audience. Politically
column17: Miller is a true child of the universities which is painfully evident in the deference he displays towards feminism and Marxism. He appears to be a master diplomat with skills which must have evolved from dealing with academic overlords for many a year. One can't help but sense that a man as level-headed as Miller sees through much of the political correctness infecting academe
column18: but that he is smart enough not to condemn the religious tenets of PC. Overall
column19: this is an excellent book and I emphatically recommend it.

column1: This long overdue biography of Jim Webb fills a needed void in the literature of the Apollo program. Webb
column2: a disarming but astute partisan Democrat from North Carolina ran NASA during the crucial years leading up to the Apollo program. This book not only details his personal life
column3: but the wheeling and dealing that went on behind the scenes in Washington to get to the moon.   Nobody doubts that Webb was brilliant
column4: but Webb was not without flaws. He was totally infatuated with Roosevelt-era New Deal big government
column5: and ran NASA accordingly
column6: sometimes to the detriment of the program. He adopted the mantra of "Space Age Management" and took it to mean a giant
column7: monolithic government run program straight from FDR's playbook. I think the book does a great job explaining Webb's less than savory relationships to politicians and others of questionable ethics in both the Kennedy and (especially) Johnson administrations such as Bobby Baker. It also recalls a less than savory battle with fellow Democrat and political climber
column8: Walter Mondale
column9: that exposes Washington political opportunism at its worst. I rate the book four stars as the book tends to downplay the significance of ethically borderline issues that occurred in Webb's tenure. To the credit of the book
column10: Bizony does correctly point out that Kennedy was not the true champion of space he is revered to be today
column11: but saw space exploration as a politically expedient course to follow
column12: as did Johnson.  On the plus side
column13: the author absolutely nails the deplorable history of NASA since Apollo and presents an accurate and devastating portrait of the Shuttle and International Space Station programs. Mr. Bizony correctly identifies the root cause of the problems in both programs as an unholy alliance of political objectives and unfocused technology. Webb's stature rose significantly in my eyes when I read Bizony's account of the hostility Webb had for Robert McNamara
column14: another big government technocrat
column15: but one without the vision of either Kennedy or Webb. NASA veteran Bob Seamans comes off as a much needed moderating force within the administration
column16: and this book also details the fascinating relationship between Seamans and Webb.   Overall this is a noteworthy book. While it occasionally seems to come off the rails and get sidetracked
column17: Piers Bizony always manages to tie up loose ends
column18: resulting in a detailed and historically important book. I recommend this book to anyone interested in the space program
column19: and further to students of management to learn not only the successes
column20: but failures of the biggest single peacetime logistical puzzle in history

Two recent books about megalomaniacs: genial
column2: larger-than-life luminaries of the food and wine world
column3: Robert Parker
column4: the American wine critic
column5: and Bernard Loiseau
column6: the French chef. They both tell of youthful talent that became increasingly ambitious as it ripened. Parker
column7: the most powerful individual in the wine industry
column8: ultimately claimed virtual infallibility; Loiseau
column9: anointed with three Michelin stars but beset with doubts
column10: ultimately committed suicide.  The Perfectionist is the saga of Bernard Loiseau
column11: big
column12: outwardly gregarious and confident
column13: inwardly shy and insecure
column14: whose traveling salesman father apprentices him
column15: as a teenager
column16: to the chef at his favorite restaurant. As it happens
column17: while young Bernard is flailing away at his first kitchen tasks
column18: the Michelin guide awards the restaurant three stars. Bernard
column19: who's a competent though not exceptional cook
column20: is awestruck: winning those three stars for himself become his life's obsession.  Bernard is fortunate to find a patron who sets him up at a country inn
column21: the famous C√¥te d'Or in Saulieu
column22: a once-thriving market town in northern Burgundy now bypassed by the autoroute. No matter: Bernard settles in for the long haul. He assembles a talented team for his kitchen and dining room
column23: he courts the Parisian press
column24: he develops a network of local suppliers. He's unlucky in love (his first wife cheats on him with the maitre d'h√¥tel) but has a knack for the restaurant business (food journalists adore him); he wins back a Michelin star for venerable auberge
column25: then two.  Now
column26: as Bernard puts it
column27: the trouble with success in the restaurant world is
column28: "C'est jamais gagn√©." The battle's never over. First you strive for ten or twenty years to reach the top. It's not like training for the Olympics
column29: where a single perfect routine wins you the gold medal; you've got to score a ten every day
column30: twice a day. But then
column31: after you've won
column32: you panic even more: now that you've been given those stars
column33: what if they take them away?  And poor Bernard
column34: though happily married to his second wife
column35: was bipolar. Mostly manic: that was the perfectionist his staff knew
column36: the outgoing giant the adored by the media and the public.   (He was ebulliant
column37: too
column38: when I met him in Saulieu in the fall of 1998
column39: eager to discuss his plans for a new bistro in Paris--eventually three--and an unprecendented plan to raise money by being listed on the Paris stock exchange.)  Then third Michelin star came along
column40: and it seemed Bernard could do no wrong. But the tentacles of darkness were stronger than anyone knew.   A slight slip in one of the guidebooks
column41: a rumor that his third Michelin star was in jeopardy
column42: a change in the culinary fashion dictated by Paris critics: it all took its toll on Bernard.   His manic-depressive disorder--easy to diagnose in retrospect--was never treated. The right medications
column43: it's assumed
column44: could have saved him from his private demons. Instead he succumbed.   Rudolph Chelminsky
column45: a keenly observant foreign correspondent
column46: had already written one of the liveliest books about gastronomy
column47: The French At Table
column48: some 20 years ago. This longevity--critical to professional acceptance in France--and his deep understanding of French culinary history gave him unprecedented access to all the actors in this drama
column49: including Bernard himself over a period of many years.   You taste Bernard's recipes
column50: savor his enthusiasm for hospitality on every page. Even as you cringe at his effusiveness
column51: you savor his generosity.   In the end
column52: you mourn his death
column53: but when the latest Michelin guide again awards his restaurant three stars
column54: you recognize that Bernard Loiseau's spirit lives on.  A footnote to compare this book to William Echikson's Burgundy Stars
column55: also about Loiseau. Chelminsky does everything that Echikson fails to do: he shows us how haute cuisine comes about. I read Burgundy Stars with mounting frustration at a writer whose research consisted of showing up and taking notes; I finished The Perfectionist with heady admiration for the author and his subject. That's the difference between blogging and real journalism.

column1: A forbidding mansion far from town

column3: a mute young woman who works for the ill matriarch
column4: a spiral staircase that goes down to the shadowy basement...and a killer who strangles women who are "imperfect."  The Spiral Staircase may not be full of frights
column5: but it is an eerie exploration of suspense. The mansion itself is a great prop. Lit by candles and gas light
column6: the rooms
column7: covered with flocked wallpaper
column8: are filled with flickering shadows
column9: deep velvet curtains
column10: carved marble fireplaces and dark oaken tables. Helen Capel (Dorothy McGuire)
column11: who became mute when she was a child
column12: works there as a maid. She helps care for Mrs. Warren (Ethel Barrymore)
column13: the bedridden
column14: ill and strong-willed matron of the house. Mrs. Warren has a son
column15: Steve Warren (Gordon Oliver)
column16: an unreliable ne'er-do-well
column17: and a stepson
column18: Professor Albert Warren (George Brent). She has no illusions. "They are both weaklings
column19: she says.   In the village, young women are being strangled...one had a limp, another was simple minded, one had a scar on her face. It's not long before we realize Helen is on the killer's list, and that the killer is most likely someone who lives in the Warren mansion. One person who seems drawn to Helen is Dr. Parry (Kent Smith), the new physician in the village. He is convinced that Helen can be made to speak and wants to take her to Boston for treatment. Mrs. Warren, although bedridden and often irascible, is no fool about the murders. When Helen is late coming home in the evening from the village, Mrs. Warren tells her, Come here. I'd hoped you were never coming back. You should run away. Leave this house tonight if you know what's good for you!" During the long night
column20: however
column21: the killer shows his determination to make Helen his next victim.  It's not too hard to figure out who the killer most likely is. Since Dorothy McGuire is the star of the movie
column22: it's also unlikely that her character will be killed. What makes this movie work so well
column23: in my opinion
column24: are several elements. First
column25: not whether Helen will be killed
column26: but what dangers will Helen face unable to call for help
column27: including a final confrontation with the killer? Second
column28: who among the supporting cast will be killed? There is the professor's secretary
column29: Blanche (Rhonda Fleming)
column30: the cook (Elsa Lanchester)
column31: her husband (Rhys Williams) and the nurse (Sara Algood). It's unlikely all will live. Third
column32: the production values of the movie. The Spiral Staircase is beautifully staged and filmed
column33: with each shot framed for maximum creepy effect. The descent to the basement
column34: where one killing takes place and another is attempted
column35: is almost worth the price of the DVD itself. The place is deeply shadowed with wooden trusses and brick walls
column36: piles of cut wood and an axe
column37: heavy casks and rows of cobwebbed wine bottles...so many places to hide
column38: and the only light coming from candles so easy to blow out. Fourth
column39: the killings are subtly handled
column40: which makes them all the more unsettling. The murderer is never shown until the end. Before then we only see his eyes. We never see the actual killings
column41: either
column42: only black shadow and white hands clutching at the air. And fifth
column43: the performances of Dorothy McGuire and Ethel Barrymore. McGuire
column44: in my view
column45: was a fine actress with an innate quality of goodness about her. We worry about Helen because of McGuire's skill and personality. Barrymore was a dominant actress in all her roles. Here
column46: bedridden
column47: she must act with her eyes and her face. She becomes an implacable old woman who sees that justice is done.   The Anchor Bay DVD has an excellent picture and audio. There are no significant extras

column1: What does it take to get your customers to see the light

column1: I am compelled to add my comments here because I disagree completely with those of K. Unger
column2: the first of the reviews here. Etty's diary is not a "book" that can be reviewed the way one reviews a novel.  This is  an historical document--a journal and letters--and Etty's intention when  writing was not to weave a narrative for some future reader
column3: but to explore  her own character--her faults
column4: desires
column5: dreams
column6: and place in the world.  Unger calls her "self-involved and lazy;" I would say that she is  profoundly self-aware
column7: self-critical
column8: and attempting to create an  intellectual life for herself. This intellectual life requires her to sit  at her desk--reading
column9: thinking
column10: writing. The value of the work is that it  allows us to watch as her mature self unfolds
column11: as she struggles with both  personal issues and the increasingly threatening political situation. If  you come to this book prepared to allow Etty to lead you along the path she  follows
column12: a path which leads ultimately to acceptance of her fate
column13: you will  come away awed and moved by the power of the human heart and mind

This book is an excellent display of how the French and Indian war fits into a European context. The only reason I would not give it five stars is that it loses the global context that is really essential to the war.  Fowler covers not only the crucial Indian involvement but the sheer hopelessness of a French Victory.  He clearly lays out how the war unfolded and what each side had to gain. He shows how the British reorganize their systems in America and bring about an eventual victory.  The British victory is put in the context of what it means for the American Revolution a little over a decade away

The Art of the Incredibles is an epic journey in its own right beyond the smash motion picture release from Disney and Pixar. Reading the interviews from Pixar giants like Brad Bird and John Lasseter on the impetus that began the In-cred-uh-ble (never mind) journey for the movie feels like you're sitting in a conference room at Pixar headquarters being debriefed on the joy and pain that brought an age-old story about fathers that want to be the super-heroes of their kids' dreams into a CGI medium that made its expression all the more enjoyable. The term "eye candy" doesn't even begin to talk about the content of this book
column2: as collage after collage and drawing after drawing illustrative the evolutionary process employed by Pixar and other bleeding-edge animation studios to breath life into characters that in turn produce a realistic
column3: enjoyable
column4: and profitable film. I purchased this book for my brother
column5: as he wants to be a storyboard artist for Pixar or ILM (Lucas' Industrial Light and Magic) one day. It really serves it's purpose to help him think about the creative process and realize his true potential in this field. As a CGI fan
column6: I'm impressed by the ability of Pixar's technical team to innovate new technology (such as sub-surface light scattering that removes the "plastic look" of Toy Story and gives the human characters more human appearance) for their projects. If you're a fan of Pixar
column7: CGI
column8: or good art in general
column9: this book will serve you well on a coffee table or near an artist's drawing table

column1: For most of us
column2: good self-esteem and good self image drives us to do great things ... make more money
column3: create a home for our family
column4: be the best kind of person we can be
column5: and do right in the world. But for Debrah Constance
column6: not having any self-esteem and being labeled "Fat Stupid Ugly" pushed her to help a displaced community deal with life's hardest issues -- drug addictions
column7: gang violence
column8: single parenting
column9: school drop outs
column10: and death. Debrah is the founder of "A Place Called Home
column11:
a South Central Los Angeles youth center that provides at risk children, ages nine to twenty, with a secure, positive family environment where they an regain  hope and belief, earn trust and self-respect and learn skills to lead to a productive life. Debrah's memoir chronicles her life as an abused child who thought so little of herself she endured deep psychological and emotional problems, drug and drinking addictions and abusive relationships throughout her life. After a life long struggle with her poor self image, she found a way to change her pattens, get help for her drug/alcohol problems and give back to children who have lost hope. This is an amazing person. I found hope and direction for my own life after reading it. I hope I get an opportunity to meet her one day so I can thank her. Her story belongs on the Oprah show so that other people can learn that even when the most unfortunate situation occurs ... there is hope. Thank you Debrah!

Jaco's first solo record proves to be the most important and influential recording in the history of the electric bass.  I invite listeners from all other forms of music to try and find another bass player other than old jazz cats like Charles Mingus and Scott LaFaro who did more for the bass than Jaco has.  He single-handedly showed us new directions we could take the instrument in.  Modern players like Victor Wooten
column2: Marcus Miller
column3: Flea
column4: and Les Claypool owe an immense debt to Jaco Pastorius.  This record holds even more weight
column5: because it was recorded all the way back in 1976.  Jaco totally revolutionized the electric bass.  'Donna Lee
column6: ' an arrangement of a Miles Davis song
column7: is just about the closest you could get to a bassist who 'shreds' in the style of monster guitarists like Malmsteen and Vai.  Every note is played clean and clear - Pastorius is a perfectionist and he makes no mistakes on this opening piece.  This is followed by the only track with vocals
column8: 'Come On
column9: Come Over.'  It features Sam and Dave on vocals
column10: and I predict that one day Quentin Tarantino will use it in one of his movies.  Pastorius shows his versatility through his mastering of natural harmonics on the sublime 'Portrait of Tracy.'  He also shows his versatility in playing slow using plenty of vibrato and slides in other tracks like 'Ocus Pocus' and 'Continuum.'  Keep your ears open for elements that would sprout up in all forms of music from Rock to Rap to Hip-Hop to Country following this debute record.    In my opinion
column11: the true highlight of this record is 'Used to be a Cha-Cha' which is another arrangment of Charlie Parker's 'Ah Leu Cha' which is also covered by Miles Davis on his ROUND BOUT MIDNIGHT lp.  The track features Herbie Hancock and is a fusion barnburner full of solos from Hubert Laws
column12: Hancock
column13: and an hypnotic looping bass line from Jaco.  The alternate take bonus track on this edition is a gem

column1: The poem of 'Piers the Ploughman' is often considered to be anonymously composed
column2: as the name William Langland was less an authorial designation as it was an inscription on the back of a manuscript - it would be as if I would be assigned the authorship of the O.E.D. because
column3: in some future time
column4: the only remaining copy was missing the title pages
column5: but still had the hard-cover with my 'ex libris' impression on it. Be that as it may
column6: Langland is considered at least as likely an author as any other
column7: and becomes a sort of stand-in
column8: an 'everyman' for his time period. A few details of this Langland are known - he was a wanderer
column9: a constant reviser (the poem goes through several revisions that scholars have designated as texts A
column10: B
column11: and C (and some argue for Z). This is not a spiritual autobiography
column12: as J.F. Goodridge states in an essay about Langland in another edition
column13: but there are no doubt autobiographical elements in the text. That the lead character is named 'Will' helps in this identification.   This poem stands alongside Chaucer's 'Canterbury Tales' as one of the great products of Middle English; this also has the character of being a different sort of Middle English than Chaucer's more courtly
column14: continental influenced variety. Thus
column15: it gives breadth to the history of the English language. Langland is often ranked as a great English poet on a par with Spenser
column16: Milton
column17: Wordsworth and Yeats
column18: as representative of his age both in topics as well as language facility.   This epic poem deals with themes familiar for the time - like Dante and Milton
column19: Langland deals with the grand ideas of the meaning of life and the destiny of humankind. However
column20: unlike Dante and Milton
column21: Will and Piers the Ploughman do not go through a mystical
column22: otherworldly adventure or journey
column23: but rather stays rooted to the earth. These are dream sequences
column24: but these too need not be otherworldly - they are things that can happen to every person. The ideas of the seven deadly sins
column25: the virtues
column26: the church
column27: and the images of heaven and hell are very much rooted to regular society images of the same. The discussion of the allegorical characters
column28: aptly named Do-Well
column29: Do-Better
column30: and Do-Best
column31: does much for the moral teaching of this poem
column32: which would have been of primary concern to the author.   Langland's text is often more Old English than Chaucerian in ways. It is far more alliterative
column33: a strong component taken from Old English. Also
column34: it is less metrical in rhythm than Chaucer - there is a pause in each line akin to older English poetry
column35: but the metre is less secure.   This translation is done in alliterative verse by E. Talbot Donaldson (the 'E' stands for the very olde Englishe sounding name of Ethelbert).  There are notes
column36: essays and other helpful material provided by Elizabeth Kirk and Judith Anderson.   There are over 50 non-related texts of the poem that have survived the Middle Ages
column37: that vary from minor to major changes throughout. Reconciling these is rather like attempting to reconcile the gospels of the Bible
column38: and then adding to that task the discovery of other non-canonical gospels. It leads to rich discussion
column39: but less agreement.   The introductory material helps set the stage for reading
column40: and the appendix gives a more thorough development of 'The Dreamer' from the C text.    Perhaps one of the reasons I like this text so much is that the persons involved were known to me
column41: or friends of friends.  Donaldson was the founding editor of 'The Norton Anthology of English Literature'
column42: a broad
column43: wide-ranging text.  However
column44: it was 'Piers Plowman' that was to be a continuing favourite study for him.   This is one of the classics of English literature
column45: perhaps the least known among them.

column7: though the RSV note indicates that its translators already knew which was the more correct. So also Genesis 1:1 now follows what was a note in the RSV: "In the beginning when God created the heavens and the earth."  Antiquated terms were replaced --  "Dome" helpfully supersedes "firmament" in Genesis I. "Behold" is handled by a variety of clever means: `look

column9: just then
column10: see here
column11: suddenly
column12: here is." "Rejoiced exceedingly" becomes "overwhelmed with joy"; "he opened his mouth" becomes "he began to speak" "he knew her not" becomes he "had no marital relations with her."  Some of its nice "corrections" are vivid and pithy: "bombastic nonsense" replaces "loud "boasts of folly" in 2 Peter 2:18; the Gerasene demoniac is now "howling
column13: not just crying out" (Mark 5:5) ; the Shulammite maiden in Song of Solomon is now "black and beautiful
column14: not just dark
column15: but comely" (1:5)
column16: and her lover's "intention toward me was love" (RSV: "his banner over me was love" -- 2:4) Saul no longer is "prophesying

column18: and "outlaws" replace Jephthah's "worthless fellows" (Judges. 11:3)  Adam and Eve did not make "aprons
column19: since kitchens had not yet been invented, but loincloths" (Gen. 3:7) The RSV's "great men" are now "magnates" (Rev. 6:15) who behave like "tyrants" (RSV: "exercise authority" -- Mark 10:42) The stilled sea is "a dead calm" (RSV: "great calm" -- Mark 4:39)
column20: and acting "by nature" is now to "do instinctively" (Rom. 2:14)  A modest clarification - The angel with which Jacob wrestled did not merely touch the hollow of his thigh on the sinew of the hip (RSV)
column21: but rather "struck Jacob on the hip socket at the thigh muscle" (Gen 32:32) And speaking of wrestling

column24: and not one of the "men of note among the apostles" (RSV) ; she is rather a woman "prominent among the apostles" and a believer before Paul was (Rom. 16:7)  The "believing wife" in I Corinthians 9:5
column25: when the RSV has merely "wife" is a faithful translation
column26: the Koine Greek reads "sister as wife" -- sister denoting a member of the church.  "Super-apostles" (for "superlative apostles" -- 2 Cor: 11:5) ; or "to be our way of life" (for "that we should walk in them" -- Eph 2:10) Advice for slaves has been clarified

Thus the leader of the synagogue "kept saying" (RSV: "said") ' to the crowd that healings should not take place on the sabbath (Luke 13:14)   The RSV's awkward "In these you once walked

column1: "Sunshine Superman" remains to this day Donovan's greatest work
column2: a pioneering masterpiece which ranks as one of the best albums of all time.  That the 19-year-old could write and perform a work so ahead of its time--he was working on the same artistic level as The Beatles
column3: who were recording "Revolver" during the same months--seems astonishing today
column4: but it took forty years for a proper version of the album to be released.    "Sunshine Superman" originally appeared in September 1966 in the US only in "reprocessed stereo"
column5: and when it was finally released in the UK in June of '67 (which made it seem less pioneering than it was in those heady times) it was combined with songs from "Mellow Yellow" in a mono version that sounded OK but in spite of the clear genius of the songwriting and arrangments
column6: the sound on both versions seemed "off" and the CD versions up to this point did nothing to improve matters.  Finally
column7: forty years later
column8: some wizard at EMI properly remastered the sound and the results are astonishing: the acoustic guitars
column9: sitars
column10: tablas
column11: harpsichords and organs have a deep
column12: rich resonance to them which wraps around the listener's ear like a fine silk tapestry.    The album contains not a single weak track and although the pace towards the end of the first side slows to a crawl (with three slow tracks in a row)
column13: all are gorgeous.  The title track and "Season Of The Witch" were memorable psychedelic rockers
column14: while stoned ballads like "Three Kingfishers" and "Guinevere" are awash in a dreamy
column15: novel synthesis of Indian and Celtic influences that is simply intoxicating. The combination of acoustic and electric guitars
column16: electric violin
column17: harpsichord
column18: strings
column19: sitars and tablas made it one of the first pyschedelic reocords and Donovan has since belatedly been recognized for his contributions to the movement
column20: his influence on The Beatles being particularly strong (see The White Album).    The next two albums
column21: "Mellow Yellow" and "A Gift From A Flower To A Garden" were equally focused and essential but "Sunshine Superman" remains his greatest
column22: both lyrically and musically
column23: and the measure by which all of his later works were compared. This remastered version also contains the essential outtakes "Breezes Of Patchulie"
column24: "Museum" and "Superlungs" which are all in the same breathtaking mold as the album (all three should have been included
column25: actually
column26: and "Museum" and "Superlungs" may have balanced the album a bit more with rockers
column27: but both found their way in satisfactory versions on later works)
column28: as well as a few acoustic demos never before released. In all
column29: an essential purchase for all Donovan fans
column30: who have been waiting years and years for something like this to come out--and unlike some reviewers here
column31: I thought the liners were fine and quite detailed.

column1: Back in the late 1960s Jim Kitses wrote an enjoyable study of three western directors who at the time were not nearly as highly regarded as they are today. His chapters on Anthony Mann and Budd Boetticher were marvelous because both directors had pretty much completed their contibutions to the western genre. The chapter on Sam Peckinpah left something to be desired since
column2: at the time
column3: Peckinpah had only three feature films--all of them westerns--under his belt. This new edition addresses that problem by providing a career-length reassessment of Peckinpah's contributions to the western. The other new material--mainly on John Ford and Clint Eastwood--is certainly readable
column4: but I'm not certain that it was essential. Nevertheless it is good to have this volume back in print once more.

column1: If you are a serious artist then you will probably have to study a few perspective books before you learn all you need to know about the subject. This book deserves to be in that collection. It covers the nuts and bolts of the correct methods for drawing in one
column2: two and three point perspective and offers hints for shortcuts that you can use to build drawings with a perspective look
column3: even if they are not technically accurate
column4: when you have to work with a deadline.   What I like about the book is that it provides thorough context for understanding not just the how
column5: but the reasons behind the perspective techniques. If you know the rules you can do it
column6: but if you understand the context in depth you can make informed decisions about when to follow the painstaking rules and when to use the shortcuts.  The book is also written in a very approachable visual medium. Basically it is a comic book following in the tradition of Scott McCloud's "Understanding Comics".  The book also includes some facinating bits of trivia about 3 point perspective
column7: when it was developed and why
column8: and the lengths that some artists
column9: like M. C. Escher
column10: had to go to in order to properly employ it.  The book has two shortcomings. The first is a consequence of its comic format
column11: there are a large number of pages which present more character development than is strictly necessary to get the information across. By contrast
column12: most perspective books are very condensed
column13: explaining as much as can be explained with illustrations and diagrams. This not only goes into detailed discussion of perspective
column14: its uses and theory
column15: but does so within the voice baloons of two characters.  The second shortcoming is one that I can't think of any other perspective book that treats
column16: that is
column17: it leaves out curvileniar or 5 point perspective
column18: though apparently the author is aware of this kind of perspective
column19: he tantalizes us by using it in a couple of illustrations in the book

column1: This is the first 'for dummies' workout that I have bought and I really like it.  It's a good dvd if you haven't done a ball workout before.  You focus on stability and balance and building up your core strength.  But because you use weights too
column2: you also get good toning for the whole body.  They use your regular overhead presses and ab work too.  She gives you optional moves if you want to make it harder or easier and tells you what not to do wrong.   Don't be fooled by thinking you can't get a good workout from a stability ball.  You will totally feel this the next day and you will be surprised with exactly how many muscles you in fact worked.  I really like this a lot

My little one just gobbled up the first recipe I made from this book and I felt so good knowing she ate a wholesome homemade meal. I know exactly what was put into it

column1: This book might seem dated: it describes the machinations of the court from 1969 to 1976
column2: which included
column3: among other things
column4: Roe v. Wade and the Watergate tapes case. However
column5: it is far from obsolete. The Brethren is a still-unprecedented look into the Supreme Court
column6: the most secretive top-level branch of government. Although the faces (save one) and the cases are different
column7: the way in which cases are decided by this body has likely not
column8: plus it is a look at a tumultous time in ours as well as the Court's history.  The focus of the story is Chief Justice Warren Earl Burger
column9: who replaces Earl Warren after his retirement. The irony of the names is unexplored
column10: but it is appropriate
column11: because Burger becomes progressively preoccupied with trying to match Warren's legacy. Unlike Warren
column12: though
column13: he allows political concerns and vanity to influence his judgment and
column14: bit by bit
column15: erode the confidence of his colleagues
column16: to the point where the late William Rehnquist
column17: then a young conservative on the Court
column18: makes fun of him behind his back. Although this book is unflattering to some of the justices
column19: such as Thurgood Marshall
column20: who is noted as lazy and uninvolved and Byron White
column21: who is noted to be unlikeable
column22: Burger is the biggest loser here. The book was published in the early 80s
column23: only a few years before Burger left the court
column24: and the image of him as a pompous
column25: preening
column26: intellectually deficient and generally clueless politician cost him
column27: big time. In spite of the landmark rulings his Court made
column28: he was unable to reverse the Warren Court's liberal activism (as he had hoped to do). His "Minnesota Twin"
column29: Harry Blackmun
column30: would drift further away from him
column31: both politically and personally
column32: until finally becoming the most liberal justice after the departure of Thurgood Marshall in 1991. Burger's Macchiavellian strategizing to assign opinions caused such a backlash that
column33: at one point
column34: William Brennan decides to vote for whatever side of a case puts him in the minority so that Burger won't be able to assign him another crappy oppinion.  Ultimately
column35: Burger had good intentions
column36: but his blunders dominate the book. He is a fascinating character
column37: almost as bad a manager and as delusional as David Brent from the recent BBC TV Series The Office. Some of the principals come out looking good: Potter Stewart
column38: for example
column39: and Brennan also. But Rehnquist comes out best
column40: in spite of some scheming and obfuscation. Burger
column41: though
column42: is front and center
column43: and he's a reminder of how we're to seriously we all should take the business of the Court

column1: This is really a super compiler text. It is also one of the most recent compiler books you can buy.  First of all this is a theoretical book. If you read the title 'Engineering a compiler' as 'Coding/Building a compiler' you would be disappointed! So
column2: if you're looking for a learing-by-coding book
column3: this is not for you (but I have some recommendations at the end of this review in the latest paragraph). The difference with most of the other theoretical books is that this book is not a dry text. It has also a nice layout. It gives plenty of examples
column4: and all topics are well connected to each other. It's a pleasure to read for not native English people
column5: so native English people can read it pretty fast.   This book read like a novel.. It does contain enough diagrams
column6: tables
column7: etc. but not too much (crowded)
column8: and everything is well explained.  You can read this book as a compiler introduction book. But I can only recommend this to B.Sc/M.Sc Computer Science students (like me). You don't need to have a M.Sc in Mathematics to understand this text
column9: (all the math
column10: eg. liveness graphs are well explained)
column11: but  you will understand everything better if you have some background in algorithms (design)
column12: pseudocode
column13: etc. like you gained during your B.Sc program. People without formal computer science education I would recommend to read a practical book first (see at the end of this review)
column14: because you may find else this text too theoretical.   This book focus on code optimizations. According to the authors (and me) compiler front ends (scanning/parsing/etc) are commodities today
column15: and the backend (codegeneration) is where the difference is made nowadays. So if you're looking for a introduction text into compiler optimization this book is for you!  If you're looking for a more practical book I advice you to read 'Programming Language Processors in Java' from Watt & Brown. In that book you learn to build a nice stack virtual machine in Java with 'advanced features' like records (structs)
column16: procedures/functions
column17: arrays and so on. That book is a good companion for 'Engineering a Compiler' to give you some practical insight. If you're looking for a Language Design book I advice you to look at 'Programming Language Pragmatics'. Both books are worth the money..
